body_html:
Ah, right, a[0] adds a strided_slice op to the graph. It's the same problem if you did sess.run(a+b), every time you run it, an Add op is added.

The way to prevent these kinds of errors is to run tf.get_default_graph().finalize() before the first session run call

If you do learning through higher level frameworks like tf.slim or MonitoredSession or estimator, those already modify the graph for you, but I guess it's a potential hazard if you stay in the low-level API
body_text:
Ah, right, a[0] adds a strided_slice op to the graph. It's the same problem if you did sess.run(a+b), every time you run it, an Add op is added.
The way to prevent these kinds of errors is to run tf.get_default_graph().finalize() before the first session run call
If you do learning through higher level frameworks like tf.slim or MonitoredSession or estimator, those  already modify the graph for you, but I guess it's a potential hazard if you stay in the low-level API
body:
Ah, right, `a[0]` adds a `strided_slice` op to the graph. It's the same problem if you did `sess.run(a+b)`, every time you run it, an `Add` op is added.
 
The way to prevent these kinds of errors is to run `tf.get_default_graph().finalize()` before the first session run call

If you do learning through higher level frameworks like `tf.slim` or `MonitoredSession` or `estimator`, those  already modify the graph for you, but I guess it's a potential hazard if you stay in the low-level API
